ResponseText: That's true, saying nature does not require the supernatural is void if nature is the supernatural. Which is why I say the word supernatural is void because no one I have ever met (nor myself) can find an objective difference between them besides the mysticism associated with one. If there was a God and he was standing right before me this very minute my first question would be 'what are you?'. Under what justification do you declare God unnatural? The triumph of reason over mysticism is far deeper than mere proof of a God. It requires something that can never happen, proof that proofs aren't required. Even so that does not defeat the christian (again looking to the catholics) view of evolution. If god made all the world so that it's rules never appear to be broken why would he break that pattern to make life?
